trans-unit.source: Using the Docker VM Extension for Linux on Azure
trans-unit.target: Using the Docker VM Extension for Linux on Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes Docker and the Azure Virtual Machines extensions, and shows how to programmatically create Virtual Machines on Azure that are docker hosts from the command line using the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Describes Docker and the Azure Virtual Machines extensions, and shows how to programmatically create Virtual Machines on Azure that are docker hosts from the command line using the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title> is one of the most popular virtualization approaches that uses <linkText>Linux containers</linkText><title></title> rather than virtual machines as a way of isolating data and computing on shared resources.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title> is one of the most popular virtualization approaches that uses <linkText>Linux containers</linkText><title></title> rather than virtual machines as a way of isolating data and computing on shared resources.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Docker VM extension managed by [Azure Linux Agent] to create a Docker VM that hosts any number of containers for your applications on Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Docker VM extension managed by [Azure Linux Agent] to create a Docker VM that hosts any number of containers for your applications on Azure.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to create a Docker VM from the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to create a Docker VM from the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: To see how to create a Docker VM at the command line, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].
trans-unit.target: To see how to create a Docker VM at the command line, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].

trans-unit.source: To see a high-level discussion of containers and their advantages, see the <linkText>Docker High Level Whiteboard</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see a high-level discussion of containers and their advantages, see the <linkText>Docker High Level Whiteboard</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The first step requires an Azure VM from a Linux image that supports the Docker VM Extension, using an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the Image Gallery as an example server image and Ubuntu 14.04 Desktop as a client.
trans-unit.target: The first step requires an Azure VM from a Linux image that supports the Docker VM Extension, using an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the Image Gallery as an example server image and Ubuntu 14.04 Desktop as a client.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, click + New in the bottom left corner to create a new VM instance and select an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the selections available or from the complete Image Gallery, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, click + New in the bottom left corner to create a new VM instance and select an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the selections available or from the complete Image Gallery, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only Ubuntu 14.04 LTS images more recent than July 2014 support the Docker VM Extension.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only Ubuntu 14.04 LTS images more recent than July 2014 support the Docker VM Extension.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Ubuntu Image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Ubuntu Image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After the VM has been created, ensure that Docker is installed on your client computer.
trans-unit.target: After the VM has been created, ensure that Docker is installed on your client computer.

trans-unit.source: (For details, see <linkText>Docker installation instructions</linkText><title></title>.)
trans-unit.target: (For details, see <linkText>Docker installation instructions</linkText><title></title>.)

trans-unit.source: Create the certificate and key files for Docker communication according to [Running Docker with https] and place them in the **~/.docker** directory on your client computer.
trans-unit.target: Create the certificate and key files for Docker communication according to [Running Docker with https] and place them in the **~/.docker** directory on your client computer.

trans-unit.source: The Docker VM Extension in the portal currently requires credentials that are base64 encoded.
trans-unit.target: The Docker VM Extension in the portal currently requires credentials that are base64 encoded.

trans-unit.source: At the command line, use **base64** or another favorite encoding tool to create base64-encoded topics.
trans-unit.target: At the command line, use **base64** or another favorite encoding tool to create base64-encoded topics.

trans-unit.source: Doing this with a simple set of certificate and key files might look similar to this:
trans-unit.target: Doing this with a simple set of certificate and key files might look similar to this:

trans-unit.source: To add the Docker VM Extension, locate the VM instance you created and scroll down to Extensions and click it to bring up VM Extensions, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To add the Docker VM Extension, locate the VM instance you created and scroll down to Extensions and click it to bring up VM Extensions, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: This functionality is supported in the preview portal only: https://portal.azure.com/
trans-unit.target: This functionality is supported in the preview portal only: https://portal.azure.com/

trans-unit.source: Click the + Add to display the possible VM Extensions you can add to this VM.
trans-unit.target: Click the + Add to display the possible VM Extensions you can add to this VM.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Docker VM Extension, which brings up the Docker description and important links, and then click Create at the bottom to begin the installation procedure.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Docker VM Extension, which brings up the Docker description and important links, and then click Create at the bottom to begin the installation procedure.

trans-unit.source: In the form fields, enter the base64-encoded versions of your CA Certificate, your Server Certificate, and your Server Key, as shown in the following graphic.
trans-unit.target: In the form fields, enter the base64-encoded versions of your CA Certificate, your Server Certificate, and your Server Key, as shown in the following graphic.

trans-unit.source: Note that (as in the preceding image) the 2376 is filled in by default.
trans-unit.target: Note that (as in the preceding image) the 2376 is filled in by default.

trans-unit.source: You can enter any endpoint here, but the next step will be to open up the matching endpoint.
trans-unit.target: You can enter any endpoint here, but the next step will be to open up the matching endpoint.

trans-unit.source: If you change the default, make sure to open up the matching endpoint in the next step.
trans-unit.target: If you change the default, make sure to open up the matching endpoint in the next step.

trans-unit.source: When viewing your VM in the resource group you've created, scroll down to click Endpoints to view the endpoints on the VM as shown here.
trans-unit.target: When viewing your VM in the resource group you've created, scroll down to click Endpoints to view the endpoints on the VM as shown here.

trans-unit.source: Click + Add to add another endpoint, and in the default case, enter a name for the endpoint (in this example, docker), and 2376 for both private and public ports.
trans-unit.target: Click + Add to add another endpoint, and in the default case, enter a name for the endpoint (in this example, docker), and 2376 for both private and public ports.

trans-unit.source: Leave the protocol value showing TCP, and Click OK to create the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Leave the protocol value showing TCP, and Click OK to create the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Locate and copy the name of your VM's domain, and at the command line of your client computer, type docker --tls -H tcp://dockerextension.cloudapp.net:2376 info (where dockerextension is replaced by the subdomain for your VM).
trans-unit.target: Locate and copy the name of your VM's domain, and at the command line of your client computer, type docker --tls -H tcp://dockerextension.cloudapp.net:2376 info (where dockerextension is replaced by the subdomain for your VM).

trans-unit.source: The result should appear similar to this:
trans-unit.target: The result should appear similar to this:

trans-unit.source: Once you complete the above steps, you now have a fully functional Docker host running on an Azure VM, configured to be connected to remotely from other clients.
trans-unit.target: Once you complete the above steps, you now have a fully functional Docker host running on an Azure VM, configured to be connected to remotely from other clients.

trans-unit.source: You are ready to go to the [Docker User Guide] and use your Docker VM.
trans-unit.target: You are ready to go to the [Docker User Guide] and use your Docker VM.

trans-unit.source: If you want to automate creating Docker hosts on Azure VMs through command line interface, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)]
trans-unit.target: If you want to automate creating Docker hosts on Azure VMs through command line interface, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)]
